title: PortDial - Language Resources for Portable Multilingual Spoken Dialogue Systems
segmentation: Ah, good afternoon for me as well.
So in the wonderful tradition created by colleagues and peaceful, here's me without slides.
So we're going to deviate a bit from the discussions you've heard throughout the.
Today we're moving into more of the language projects of this call port dial.
What's a cold?
Well portal is all about spoken dialogue systems, so the datasets that we're talking about in spoken dialogue systems are speech recordings which we use to train acoustic models.
We're talking about text data, which we used to train language models were talking about creating ontologies, and about creating grammars.
So why is all that important?
Because this is what the elements that we need in order to create successful speech applications.
So what is our chat?

Alan George challenges that a major roadblock in this systems is the lack of linguistic resources which are required for us to be able to rapidly port applications from domain to domain and from language to language.
Now I do have, for example, a demo for you, which actually we needed to be able to see the translation of it because it's in Turkish.
That was to go about showing you the difficulty of taking an application that was initially created in Greek.
And porting it first to English and then to Turkish.
Since you will not be able to see the translation and probably most of you don't speak, Turkish will skip that.
You'll take my word for it that it's really very difficult to find a way to translate everything in a manner that makes sense in the language that you're porting to.
So the problem there is that it takes a lot of time and a lot of specific linguistic effort, which is talent that is hard to find.
So what is port dial in that sense portal?
Is has it's an objective to create machine aided methods.
To create, clean up and publish multi lingual ontologies and grammars.
An domains to create spoken dialogue system prototypes.
The idea is to create a platform that will make this cost effective.
An offer good time to market.
In order to go from domain to domain an from language language.
Um?
So.
What is the in of?
Mission that we try to bring into this process, it's to combine knowledge based and data driven approaches to create these ontologies and grammars.
Apologies what we mean by ontologies is large domains and what we mean by grammars is pretty much the list that we use to semantically interpret what a user of a spoken dialogue system has said.
So these are very important elements for a successful, usable spoken dialect system application.
So, um.

The partners to this project include three academic institutions and two SMS voiceweb, which I'm the commercial head of, is one of the beneficiaries of this, we intend to use this.
The proceedings that save this project in our business.
And the other partners include the Technological Systems Institute, which is based in Crete.
The University of Trento in the University of Delafield as well as expert systems of Italy.
OK, this will take a bit more.
So the.
Scenarios as I've already explained, is to use porting to a new domain where we focus on adapting existing applications to new domains.
For example, I have someone that has a request for a statement on his bank account, so he goes on a service and says, can you give me the latest balance on my bank account?
But that same request could be coming from someone wanting to know what his last mobile bill is.
So that is a very similar application, but in terms of domain one is banking, the other is telecom.
So the idea there is to be able to port from the banking to the telecom.
The same thing in a different approach is going to a new language, so I might have the application in Greek and want it in Turkish in Hebrew.
Alot of customers have legal requirements to present their applications in multiple of languages.
OK, so there are two scenarios for doing these two things.
One is the resource rich and the resource poor.
Difference here is that obviously we're starting with much less data.
And we need to use much more bottom up approaches for the resource port scenario.
And for you who loves seems I'm not a technical man, here is everything in.
A schematic representation.
It's pretty much what I just explained.
The two different scenarios of going about it.
So the idea again is to use this fund into creating something that has a long lasting effect.
That is something that is used in our business and the way we're going to do that is by creating a platform that would enable us to do rapid prototyping of new services.
To give an example, we have a customer that requires an application in four different languages.
So the thing for us is to just create it in one and be able to translate to the other three.
So you see the languages that are covered.
What we also want to do is to have available also the resources part of them in an in public data that can be used by research institutions.
And also have a part which is paid data which will be used by esimees all around the world.
Thus what we hope to do is to lower the barrier to entry for other SMS to get into this line of business.
And to, let's say, increase the pie for everyone speech, as you might be all aware of Siri and other things, speech is is a medium that becoming ubiquitous.
So we want to ride on that wave.
So with that I leave you.
I thank you for bearing with me with no slides.

Thank you.
